headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: New Study Links Insomnia to Heat Attacks; Inflation Picked up in January; Movement Toward Non-Alcoholic Beer. Aired 8:30-9a ET

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: A new study released moments ago suggesting that your lack of sleep, or anonymous (ph) collectively on this show -

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Bad news for us.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Could be affecting our heart health. Dr. Sanjay Gupta here to explain.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Do you know what that white stuff is? Oh, well, now you can't see it. All right, Hollywood certainly has a lot of stars, but the West Coast is on alert for lots of snow over the next 48 hours. You're looking at a light dusting of snow on the Hollywood sign as southern California braces for a rare blizzard. Up to 7 feet of snow expected in some areas out west. CNN will keep you updated on this storm.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: No way the Minnesota girl thinks that's snow.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I just think it's so funny! Yes, all things are -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Poppy's like, please.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All things are relative.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Call me when L.A. gets 7 inches of snow, right?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, right.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That would be amazing.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: How big of a link did this study find between insomnia and cardiovascular disease, Sanjay?

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: I've got to say, first of all, I love doing these kinds of stories with morning anchors.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: We're probably like --

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: I know how much of a premium sleep is for you. So, just, you know, when you listen to this, you got to remember this is an association study. So they found that people who had insomnia did have a greater risk of different things, including cardiovascular disease. But it could be people who have insomnia have other issues as well. Just keep that in mind.They also defined insomnia, first of all, very specifically, as people who had difficulty initiating sleep, people who had difficulty maintaining sleep and people who they would wake up and then have difficulty going back to sleep. So, just keep that in the mind of your mind in terms of what insomnia specifically is. This was a significant study in terms of size. And I think that's why it's getting attention. More than a million people, several countries around the world, looked at insomniacs, looked at people who did not have insomnia, and said, what is the likelihood of having a heart attack. It's low in both cases here. To be clear, 1.6 percent versus 1.2 percent. But that is a significantly higher number in the insomniacs, of having these trouble with heart problems. So, I think that's what got the researchers' attention and that's what's going to probe them to sort of figure out what they can do about this, what they can advise.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Can I just follow up with Sanjay, please.Sanjay, I'm being totally serious here, I got everything you just described is me. That's me on this shift.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: I can imagine, Don. And you, obviously, had a significant shift from your schedule before to the schedule now.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: The total opposite.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: And, you know, if you look at overall in the world, at any given time, about one in two people say that they suffer from short- term insomnia. About one in ten people say they have long term insomnia, chronic insomnia. So, it's a significant problem.And I do think that a lot of this has to do with the fact that as we, as humans, have moved further and further indoors and are getting less natural light on our faces and in our eyes and that opportunity to reset our body clock on a regular basis, our circadian rhythm, it's really just thrown off our sleep schedules. We've known this for some time. We've down it's probably a problem. But now the studies are coming out to sort of show that, you know, how significant a problem it is. And, by the way, less than five hours of sleep, problematic, but also greater than nine hours could be problematic. So, there is a sweet spot here. It's not necessarily that more is better.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Is there a difference, Sanjay, between insomnia and just not having enough hours to sleep? Like --

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Yes, there is. And that's a really - it's a really important point because they're -- when they defined insomniacs, they specifically said that it was this difficulty where people might have disturbances in sleep patterns throughout the night. They may be in bed for a long period of time, but in terms of actually defining the number of hours of sleep where the absolute number of hours of sleep where it became problematic it was less than five hours. As you've heard, we've long heard, seven to eight hours is probably that sweet spot. But when you saw the greatest increase in health problems overall, it's when people were getting fewer than five hours on a regular basis.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, man.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Don just volunteered to be a case study for your next investigation into this.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I'm serious. I could be. Seriously, though, I could.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I could.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's a real - it's a real thing that people have. And, you know, my little sister was - we were talking about this recently, she struggles with this. And we were talking about, should she get a weighted blanket, should she do this, should she read before bed? You know, if you do have this, Sanjay, what do you do if you have insomnia? GUPTAyou know, there's all sorts of different sleep recommendations that people have heard certainly over the years. Make sure you have good sleep hygiene. You know, not using devices before you go to bed. Keep the room cool and dark. Having that sleep schedule. I think the middle point here, getting enough natural light during the day, Kaitlan, I think is a really important one. We spend so much of our lives indoors now and surrounded by artificial light. And I think what we are seeing, as I mentioned earlier, is how -- just how disruptive that is to our circadian rhythms overall. If you get outside and you get outside at the time of day when it's light, so you're actually exposing your eyes first thing in the morning to natural light and making sure you get as much natural light throughout the day as possible, as the light changes throughout the day, the impact of that light on your body and brain should change throughout the day as well, that's what probably is the most important in terms of getting your clock, your circadian clock, on rhythm and, you know, best beating your chance of having insomnia.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Good advice.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I'm serious. I am going to talk to you after this because on this schedule, sometimes I can barely form a sentence. It's - it's crazy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I'm going to buy you a weighted blanket.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I have a -- I have two weighted blankets.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You do?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: A friend told me last night, Sanjay, transcendental meditation.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I've done that. I still do it.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All right, I'm going to keep coming up with ideas.Dr. Sanjay Gupta.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Don's tried it all.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: All right, Don, give me a call. I've got a few other suggestions for you.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Got a medical mystery on our hands.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Sanjay.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Sanjay.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Just in, a key consumer spending report is out. It is how the Fed -- the questions is, how will the Fed gauge this inflation number. We'll tell you about them, next.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All right, just in, a key consumer spending report just released. It is the Fed's preferred gauge of inflation.Chief business correspondent Christie Romans is here sighing.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh, what is that sigh for?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Sighing for us on a Friday morning.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN CHIEF BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Deep sigh. Well, 5.4 percent was the inflation gauge on this PCE index. And that's hotter than we had expected. And it's the first time we've seen it tick up in quite a few months here. So, overall inflation, 5.4 percent. Still far away from the Fed's desired 2 percent.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You just answered my question, is it a trend overall?

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: It's not a trend overall. It's just one kind of icky (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: No, I meant going down overall. Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Yes, the trend has been peaking, but still we're far away from that - from that 2 percent. And that's what the Fed wants to see.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Speaking of the Fed, I thought it was interesting that Jamie Dimon, obviously, head of JP Morgan Chase - ROMANS

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Said yesterday on CNBC, I have all the respect for Powell, the Fed chair, but then he said, we lost a little bit of control of inflation.Does that worry you to hear someone like Jamie Dimon think -

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Well, Jamie Dimon is -- his business is to be worried about bad things that are going to happen, right? And you remember he talked about a hurricane was coming way earlier last year and he's been worried about a recession for some time.I think that that has been the risk and the concern broadly, even inside the Fed, that inflation, once it gets out of control, it is really hard to get it back in the bottle. That's why the Fed has raised interest rates so many times so quickly and by so much, they're trying to get this under control.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Can you just remind us why 2 percent is the goal. Why did they settle on 2 percent?

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Two percent is the goal internally. A lot of central banks use as their goal. That's where inflation is healthy. A little bit of price increases are healthy in an economy. Deflation is not. So, a little bit of inflation. And you want to have a strong job market. We still have a very strong job market. That spins off more inflation, by the way, and higher wages.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: So, look, the Fed's got a really hard job, and this is just another data point that shows that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's your job to worry too. Not just Jamie Dimon.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: She worries in size (ph) for us.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You worry about everything.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: I am rainbows and unicorns. It is Friday.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Romans, very much.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Christine "inflation" Romans.All right, alcohol sales have slipped over the past two years. More people are thirsting for boozeless beer. Maybe one person at this table. Why is this morning's number 153? Harry Enten is here with alcohol-free beer to tell us why, next.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: We're just talking about beer in the studio.So, are you ready for your big Friday night. Maybe leave the beer at home. More people are becoming sober curious, and the companies behind your favorite booze are really taking notice of this. Here, our senior data reporter, Harry - Harry Enten. So, what is this number and what is this beer? What - what?

utterances.speaker: HARRY ENTEN, CNN SENIOR DATA REPORTER
utterances.sentences: OK. So this morning's number is, 153 percent. So, non-alcoholic beer searches on Google this January and February are up 153 percent from 2018 and up, 27 percent from 2022. And I know I hit on something when everybody in the studio was so interested in this topic. People actually think that this stuff tastes pretty good. But --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. I do. I drank this during Covid, in fact.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Here you go.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: This is the only thing that I got close to alcohol with this.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Right. But the problem is, is you don't actually feel anything and you just gain the calorie count.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: But I think what's so interesting about what's going on here is, we're talking about, you know, non-alcoholic searches going up. Take a look here at alcoholic drinks in 2022. Take a look at the sales. Look, low in non-alcoholic beverages still trail well behind all alcoholic beverages, $188 billion to $2.5 billion in sales.But look here. Look at the change from 2021. The all-alcohol category, down 1 percent. The low and non-alcoholic, this is what I'm interested in, look at this growth level, it's up 25 percent, Don. So, this is what's being reflected in those Google searches. Right now, look, the all-alcoholic market is still the dominant market, but the fact is people are getting more and more interested in these low and non-alcoholic alternatives.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I don't think you should be surprised. I mean if the -- start at the bottom, if it's low, of course it's -- there's nowhere to go but up.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: That is true. There is nowhere to go but up.But here's what I would point out is, I do think there is this idea among alcoholic drinkers, because I'm always interested in the why, right? Why is it that non-alcoholic beverages are starting to go up, starting to become a larger share of the market? And I think we get an idea here. Alcohol has a negative effect on society at large and most people who drink. This is among alcohol drinkers. This is among alcohol drinkers. This is not people like me who don't really drink a lot of alcohol. Look at - look at this, 71 percent of society at large say alcohol has a negative effect. And look at this, most people who - most people who drink alcohol, they believe -- 65 percent of alcohol drinkers believe it has a negative effect on them.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I think that they should look at also the use of other things now, like marijuana is becoming legal.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: They're microdosing or what have you. And sometimes people just want the taste of it when they're already using a substance that can help them relax or (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I think that can definitely be true, Don.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, thank you, Harry Enten.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: All right, don't drink this.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I'm going to -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right, well, here's some news that might drive you to drink. One of HBO's hit shows is reportedly coming to an end.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: This is not about getting back at dad. But if it hurts him, it doesn't bother me.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: The show "Succession." The creator and show writer, Jessie Armstrong, has now told "The New Yorker" that season four of the Emmy Award winning drama, which premiers in March, will be its final season. Armstrong says, quote, he never thought this show could on forever and he wants it to go out strong. Before you get your hopes up, the FBO (ph) chief, Kacey Boy (ph), says it is unlikely there will be a spinoff of "Succession." Season four returns on March 26th. I can't wait for it, but I'm - I'm - you always want your favorite shows to end in a really great way, but you also just never want them to end.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Not a spinoff, but lots of copies on other networks trying to do what "Succession" did.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right, now to today's "Morning Moment."One of the victims of the Michigan State campus shooting got quite the surprise from his hospital bed when he received a call from his favorite NBA player, Philadelphia 76ers James Harden chatted with John Hao on Facetime. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JOHN HAO
utterances.sentences: Hi. (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: JAMES HARDEN
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE). How are you?

utterances.speaker: HAO
utterances.sentences: Good. Good.

utterances.speaker: HARDEN
utterances.sentences: Everything will work itself out, you're strong. You're all right. You're going to be all right, I promise you are.

utterances.speaker: HAO
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: HARDEN
utterances.sentences: I love when you're smiling too. I love when you're smiling.I know it's tough right now. You've just got to - you've got to stay physically strong. You know what I mean. You've got to just - you've got to think positive things and just keep pushing. You've got to keep fighting.

utterances.speaker: HAO
utterances.sentences: For sure.

utterances.speaker: HARDEN
utterances.sentences: I got you.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: What do they say at Michigan State, go green, go white, for Adrienne who is an alum there says, go green, and then you're supposed to respond, go white.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: There's good news in the world. There's a lot of good news in the world.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. COLLINS

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Glad we could share that. OK.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Glad we could share our week with you as well. Make sure you -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, thanks for joining us.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Have yourself a great weekend. We'll see you next week.
